guide.conclusion:
This project is a great example of a cybernetic, or "self-governing" system. These kinds of systems have been around since the steam age (check out fly-ball governors for an early example of the technology).

With this kind of analog robotic control system. remarkably human-like behaviour can be obtained without the need for complex digital programming.

flags.title: Weekend Project
flags.text: This project is part of RadioShack's The Great Create.

guide.introduction:
This project uses a simple 555 timer chip and a feedback loop to control a servo-controlled wooden arm. Whenever an object comes close to a photosensor mounted on the end of the arm, it blocks the amount of light detected, which triggers the arm to swat the object away.

Check out more Weekend Projects.

  • Plywood

  • Electrolytic Capacitor 1.0uF
  • Electrolytic Capacitor 1000uF

lines.text: I designed a simple frame to hold all the parts, cut from 1/4" birch plywood.

lines.text: For this design, you can use a 4" carriage bolt across the top, from which gold wire and thread can be tied to suspend the "ball," in this case, a plastic egg.

lines.text: Add the resistors: 1.5kΩ (Brown-Green-Red-Gold), 47kΩ (Yellow-Violet-Orange-Gold), 15kΩ (Brown-Green-Orange-Gold), 2.2kΩ (Red-Red-Red-Gold), 10kΩ (Brown-Black-Orange-Gold)

lines.text: Add the 1000μF and 1μF capacitors. These are polarized and need to go in the right way around.

lines.text: Add the diode. This is also polarized and needs to go in the right way around.

lines.text: Wire up the servo's red (+5v), black (Gnd), and yellow (Control) connections from the circuit on the breadboard.
lines.text_raw: Wire up the servo's red (+5v), black (Gnd), and yellow (Control) connections from the circuit on the breadboard.

lines.text: Connect the photoresistor (aka light-dependent resistor or LDR) to the circuit using wires long enough to reach up the wooden arm.
lines.text_raw: Connect the photoresistor (aka light-dependent resistor or LDR) to the circuit using wires long enough to reach up the wooden arm.

lines.text: Drill a small hole in the end of the arm to hold the photodiode and insert it. Tape the wires down the arm to the breadboard.

lines.text: Attach the wooden arm to the servomotor such that it leans slightly away from the ball. Mount the breadboard and servomotor onto the stand.
lines.text_raw: Attach the wooden arm to the servomotor such that it leans slightly away from the ball. Mount the breadboard and servomotor onto the stand.

lines.text: Connect the battery holder to the power and ground rails along the sides of the breadboard.

lines.text: The connections you may not be able to see on the breadboard (second photo) are: Diode to Pin 6 of the IC, large cap between +5V and the 6th column of holes, small cap between Ground and Pin 2 of the IC.

lines.text: I built the frame from what I had lying around. To hold the servo and breadboard, I glued down a few off-cuts of plywood.

lines.text: For the arm, I used a 6" piece of square dowel. I wrapped the photoresistor wires around it and secured them with tape.
lines.text_raw: For the arm, I used a 6" piece of square dowel. I wrapped the photoresistor wires around it and secured them with tape.

lines.text: I used jeweler's wire to secure the arm to the servo — just loop the wire around and twist it tight.
lines.text_raw: I used jeweler's wire to secure the arm to the servo — just loop the wire around and twist it tight.

lines.text: Position a desk lamp so that it shines light towards the photosensor, from the other side of the hanging object.

lines.text: Insert batteries into the battery holder and watch the fun.  If the arm swings the wrong way, turn the servomotor around.
